evidence.title: README (segment 1)
evidence.excerpt: üåê **[ascii-chat.com](https://ascii-chat.com)** - Homepage, installation, and documentation

evidence.title: README (segment 2)
evidence.excerpt: üìö **[Doxygen Documentation](https://zfogg.github.io/ascii-chat/)** - Developer API reference, architecture guides, and more

evidence.title: README (segment 3)
evidence.excerpt: Probably the first command line video chat program (let me know if this isn't true). Initial commits _November 20-24, 2013_, with [@craigpalermo](https://github.com/craigpalermo), at some collegiate hackathon.

evidence.title: README (segment 4)
evidence.excerpt: ascii-chat is a client-server application that operates over TCP/IP. It supports color and audio and crypto and compression and multiple clients and has many little features and options.

evidence.title: README (segment 5)
evidence.excerpt: The client functions by simply printing text and terminal escape codes to your terminal, so it works EVERYWHERE that terminals work: on rxvt-unicode in OpenBox, in a Putty SSH session, in iTerm and Kitty.app on macOS, and theoretically everywhere else terminals run. You just need a webcam.

evidence.title: README (segment 6)
evidence.excerpt: ascii-chat even works in an initial unix login shell. You know, the shell that runs 'startx' and launches your desktop environment so you can open a gui terminal app like Konsole or Kitty or Alacritty in kde or xfce. You don't need a desktop environment at all to video chat with ascii-chat. (\*)

evidence.title: README (segment 7)
evidence.excerpt: üÜï We support UTF-8 now so it's not just ASCII anymore. However, the name is still ascii-chat.

evidence.title: README (segment 8)
evidence.excerpt: üÜï Now 3+ simultaneous people can connect and the server will render the clients to each other as a grid, like Google Hangouts and Zoom calls do. See the **[Network Protocol docs](https://zfogg.github.io/ascii-chat/group__network.html#topic_network)**.

evidence.title: v0.8.38
evidence.excerpt: Video chat in your terminal ## Download **Two Package Types:** - **ascii-chat**: Runtime package (executable + man page + shell completions) - **libasciichat**: Development package (libraries + headers + API docs + build integration) **Linux Installers (x86_64 & arm64):** - Runtime: `ascii-chat-*.deb` or `ascii-chat-*.rpm` - .deb: `ascii-chat-*.deb`, `libasciichat-dev-*.deb` - .rpm: `ascii-chat-*.rpm`,`libasciichat-devel-*.rpm` - Archives: `ascii-chat-*.tar.gz`, `libasciichat-*.tar.gz` - Self-extracting: `ascii-chat-*.sh`, `libasciichat-*.sh` **macOS Installers (x86_64 & arm64):** - Runtime: `ascii-chat-*.pkg` - Development: `libasciichat-*.pkg` - Archives: `ascii-chat-*.tar.gz`, `libasciichat-*.tar.gz` - Self-extracting: `ascii-chat-*.sh`, `libasciichat-*.sh` **Windows Installers (x86_64):** - Installer: `ascii-chat-*.msi` (single installer with optional components) - Archives: `ascii-chat-*.zip`, `libasciichat-*.zip` ## Quick Start Choose the architecture of your computer when you download. Ask @claude how to find out your computer's architecture. $arch = amd64 (x86_64) or arm64 (aarch64) **Linux - Package Manager (no dependencies required):** ```bash sudo dpkg -i ascii-chat-v0.‚Ä¶
